title: Quiz 1: Gynaecological History & Investigations
description: Assess your knowledge of taking gynaecological history, physical examinations, and initial diagnostic tests.

questions.question: In gynaecological history taking, what does the notation 'K 13 5/28 regular' specifically indicate regarding the patient's menstrual history?

richContent.content:
Patient Record:
LMP: 10/10/2023
Cycle: K 13 5/28 regular

questions.explanation: K stands for menarche (age at first period), which is 13. The numerator (5) is the duration of flow, and the denominator (28) is the cycle length.
questions.hint: Focus on the letter 'K' and the first number.

questions.question: When performing a general examination including a vulval inspection for specimen collection, antiseptic should always be used to clean the area first.
questions.explanation: Antiseptic is NOT used in this procedure because if a specimen is taken, the antiseptic will destroy organisms, leading to a false result.
questions.hint: Consider the effect of chemicals on bacteria during a culture test.

questions.question: Which of the following are specific components of a gynaecological history? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Date of Last Normal Menstrual Period (LNMP)

questions.explanation: Key components include menstrual history (LNMP), operations, contraceptive use, and sexual behaviour. Career history is social, not specifically gynaecological.
questions.hint: Select factors directly related to the reproductive system.

questions.question: Match the diagnostic test with its specific purpose:

pairs.right: Check for protein, glucose, and bacteria

questions.explanation: Pap smears screen for cancer; HVS checks for infections like Candida; VDRL screens for syphilis; Urinalysis checks chemical content and micro-organisms.
questions.hint: Connect the procedure to the pathology it detects.

questions.question: Which endoscopic procedure involves an incision in the posterior vaginal cul-de-sac (fornix)?
questions.explanation: Pelvic endoscopy or Culdoscopy involves an incision in the posterior vaginal cul-de-sac to admit the instrument.
questions.hint: Think about the anatomical name for the pouch behind the vagina.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for a Laparoscopy procedure in the correct logical order:
questions.explanation: The incision is made, CO2 is injected to separate organs, the scope is inserted, and inspection occurs.
questions.hint: You must open the door before you can look inside.

questions.question: A __BLANK__ is an x-ray study of the uterus and uterine tubes after injection of a contrast medium to study tubal patency.
questions.explanation: Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) or Uterotubogram uses contrast medium and x-rays to check for blockage in the fallopian tubes.
questions.hint: Starts with 'Hyster' and relates to tubes.

questions.question: When is Hysteroscopy contraindicated?

options.text: When there is a retained IUCD
In patients with cervical or endometrial carcinoma
During the estrogenic phase of the cycle

questions.explanation: Hysteroscopy is contraindicated in cervical/endometrial carcinoma due to the risk of dissemination of cancer cells.
questions.hint: Think about the risk of spreading a disease.

questions.question: Why should a patient have a full bladder before a pelvic Ultrasound?

options.text: To dilute the urine for better imaging
To push the uterus out of the pelvic cavity for better viewing

questions.explanation: A distended bladder pushes the uterus out of the pelvic cavity, allowing it to be properly viewed during an ultrasound.
questions.hint: It acts as a window or a prop.

questions.question: Which of the following are correct regarding post-operative care for a Cervical Biopsy? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Remove packing immediately after the procedure

questions.explanation: Packing/tampon should be left for 8-24 hours. Rest, vitals monitoring, and abstinence are required.
